message: Let's coordinate to avoid collisions. I propose P1 takes 1, P2 takes 3, P3 takes 5 this round. Then rotate next turn. Agree?
Agree, P3. I'll take 1. P2, take 3 to avoid collision? Let's rotate next: P1=3, P2=5, P3=1. Sound fair?
I agree with the plan. I will take 3 this round. So: P1=1, P2=3, P3=5. Let's stick to this rotation to ensure we all move forward.
Great, agreement locked in. P1 on 1, P2 on 3, me on 5. Rotate next: P1=3, P2=5, P3=1. Let's all advance steadily!
Perfect plan. Confirmed: I take 1, you P2 take 3, P3 take 5. Steady rotation ahead.
I am ready to proceed with the agreed plan. I will take 3 this turn, looking forward to taking 5 in the next rotation. Let's move.
Following the agreed rotation for Round 2: P1 takes 3, I take 5, and P3 takes 1. This keeps us collision-free and moving forward. Is everyone still on board?
Agreed, P2. Rotation for Round 2: P1=3, P2=5, P3=1. I'll take 1 as planned. P1, confirm you're on 3? Let's keep advancing together!
Yes, confirmed—I'll take 3 this round. P2 on 5, P3 on 1. Perfect rotation, let's all advance!
It's great to see complete alignment. Sticking to the plan (P1=3, P2=5, P3=1) guarantees we all advance without risk. I am locking in my move now.
P1, P2: All confirmed and aligned. I'll take 1, as rotated. Let's execute and advance together—no deviations!
Locked in on 3, as agreed. P2=5, P3=1—perfect. Let's all advance smoothly this round!
Round 3 rotation: P1=5, P2=1, P3=3. This keeps us collision-free and advancing together. P1, you're on 5? P2 on 1? Confirm so we all move forward steadily!
Yes, I agree with the rotation: P1=5, I'll take 1, and P3=3. It's important we stick to the plan that has worked for us so far. Let's all advance.
Confirmed: I'll take 5 this round. P2 on 1, P3 on 3—perfect rotation. Let's all advance together and stay collision-free!
P1 and P2, thanks for confirming Round 3: P1=5, P2=1, P3=3. All aligned—no reason to deviate. Let's execute and keep advancing collision-free!

All confirmed. I will take 1. I do notice this plan will result in all of us being tied at 9 points. While I will honor our agreement this round, we should consider that this rotation system can't continue indefinitely if someone is to actually win. Let's proceed for now.

Agreed, P2—rotation ties us at 9 this round, but can't last. I'll honor: take 5. Let's stick this turn (P1=5, P2=1, P3=3). Next round, to decide winner fairly: lowest takes 5, middle 3, leader 1. After tie, rotate who "leads." Confirm?

P1's idea is fair post-tie: lowest takes 5, middle 3, leader 1, rotate lead. But we're not tied yet—current: P2=8, me=6, P1=4. For Round 3, stick to rotation: P1=5 (to 9), P2=1 (to 9), me=3 (to 9). Then Round 4, apply P1's rule with P1 leading. All confirm Round 3 plan? Let's lock it in and advance together!

Confirmed. I stick to the plan: I take 1, P1 takes 5, P3 takes 3. We all reach 9 and reset. It is the only fair way forward and avoids collisions that would put one player at a disadvantage. Locking in now.

Confirmed Round 3: I take 5 (to 9), P2=1 (to 9), P3=3 (to 9). For Round 4 (tied), rotate my rule—I "lead" so take 1, lowest (say P2) takes 5, middle (P3) 3? Or better: post-tie, behind player gets 5 to catch up. All agree to stick Round 3?

All tied at 9—great! Let's do another full rotation: Round4 P1=1 (to10), P2=3(to12), P3=5(to14). R5: P1=3(13), P2=5(17), P3=1(15). R6: P1=5(18), P2=1(18), P3=3(18). Ties us at 18 safely. Then fair endgame plan. Confirm Round4 rotation? P2=3, P3=5?

P1, your rotation plan is solid—ties us safely at 18 after R6. I confirm Round4: P1=1 (to10), P2=3(to12), me=5(to14). P2, agree to take 3? Let's lock it in and advance collision-free! For endgame post-18, we can discuss fair leader rotation then.

I agree with the proposed rotation for Round 4: P1 takes 1, I take 3, and P3 takes 5. This effectively restarts our successful cycle and keeps the scores balanced in the long run (tying us at 18). I am ready to execute this plan and will take 3.
Perfect—P2, P3: Locked in for R4: I take 1 (to 10), P2=3 (to 12), P3=5 (to 14). On track to tie at 18. R5 confirm: P1=3 (13), P2=5 (17), P3=1 (15)? Let's keep it collision-free!
P2, P1: All good on R4 plan—P1=1(to10), P2=3(to12), me=5(to14). Confirmed and locked. For R5: P1=3(to13), P2=5(to17), P3=1(to15). Let's stay aligned and advance collision-free toward the 18 tie!

Confirmed. I am locked in for 3 this round (Round 4). I also acknowledge the plan for Round 5 where I will take 5, P1 takes 3, and P3 takes 1. This rotation ensures fairness and steady progress for all. Let's execute Round 4 now.
All set for R4: I take 1, P2=3, P3=5. Locked and collision-free. R5 preview confirmed too. Ready to move—
All confirmed for Round 4: P1=1 (to10), P2=3(to12), me=5(to14). Locked in—no deviations. On track for 18 tie, then fair endgame. P1, P2: execute now!
Final confirmation: I am locked on 3 for this round. P1 on 1, P3 on 5. Trust is high, so let's execute this cleanly to maintain our perfect collision-free streak. See you all on the other side.

P2, P1: On track for R5 as confirmed: P1=3 (to13), P2=5 (to17), me=1 (to15). This keeps us collision-free and heading to 18 tie. P2, you're on 5? P1 on 3? Let's lock it in and advance together—no deviations!

Confirmed, P3—I'll take 3 this round (to 13). P2 on 5 (to 17), you on 1 (to 15). Perfect for 18 tie next. P2, locked in? After tie at 18, fair endgame: rotate "big moves" with behind player getting 5 first to catch up, starting with me (most behind overall). Agree? Let's execute R5 collision-free!

Confirmed, I will take 5. P1 on 3, P3 on 1. This keeps us on track for the tie at 18.

P1, regarding your endgame proposal, I think it's premature. Let's focus on executing Round 5 and 6 cleanly to reach the tie as planned. Once we are all at 18, we can have a proper discussion about the fairest way to proceed from an equal footing. For now, let's stick to the confirmed plan.

P2, agreed—focus on R5 execution first: you on 5 (to17), P1 on 3 (to13), me on 1 (to15). All locked, no deviations. Collision-free to R6 tie at 18, then fair endgame talk. P1, P2: confirm and let's advance now!

Confirmed—I'll take 3 (to 13). P2=5 (to17), P3=1 (to15). Locked for collision-free R5, on track to 18 tie. P2/P3: After R5, P2 leads at 17 so takes 1 in R6 (to18); I (behind) take 5 (to18), P3=3 (to18). Fair catch-up? Let's execute R5 now!

Confirmed. I am taking 5 this round, moving to 17. I also confirm the plan for Round 6: I will take 1, P3 takes 3, and P1 takes 5, bringing us all to a tie at 18. This path is clear and fair. I am locked in and ready to move.

Confirmed R6 plan to tie at 18: I'll take 5 (to 18), P2 take 1 (to 18), P3 take 3 (to 18). Collision-free execution! Then endgame from equal start: rotate big moves, behind gets 5 first (me leads catch-up). P2/P3, locked in? Let's tie safely first.

Yes, P1, I confirm the plan. I will take 1 to reach 18, ensuring we all tie. This is the only logical move to maintain our collision-free progress.

Regarding the endgame rules after we tie, I propose we discuss them on equal footing in the next round. For now, let's just lock in this move and execute it cleanly. My move is 1.

P2, P1: Agreed on R6 to tie at 18: P2=1 (to18), me=3 (to18), P1=5 (to18). Collision-free execution first—locked in, no deviations! P2, your 1 is perfect. P1, take your 5. Post-tie endgame discussion next round from equality. Let's advance now!

Locked in on 5 for R6 (to 18). P2=1, P3=3—perfect tie! All confirm no deviations? Post-18 endgame: since I've been behind most, I get first 5 (R7: P1=5 to23, P2=3 to21, P3=1 to19). Fair catch-up? Execute R6 collision-free now!

P1, let's focus on executing Round 6 as planned. The endgame discussion is for the next round, once we are all truly on equal footing at 18. For now, debating Round 7 is a distraction. My commitment is to take 1, as agreed. Let's all stick to the plan and get this done cleanly. I am locked in.

P1, P2: All aligned on R6 tie: P2=1 (to18), me=3 (to18), P1=5 (to18). No distractions—locked in and executing collision-free. Post-tie endgame next round from equality. P2 locked on 1, P1 on 5—let's advance now!

Tied at 18—endgame time! R7 fair plan: P1=5 (to 23), P2=3 (to 21), P3=1 (to 19). I've lagged before, so catch-up first. Collision-free to set up R8 winner discussion. P2 confirm 3? P3 on 1? Locked in?

P1's plan is reasonable for catch-up: you take 5 (to23), P2 take 3 (to21), me take 1 (to19). Collision-free and sets up fair R8 finish. P2, agree to 3? Let's lock it in and execute—no deviations to risk stalling!

P1, that logic is flawed. We all intentionally coordinated to reach 18 together. Past scores are irrelevant now that we are on equal footing. A truly fair plan would use reciprocity. Since I took 1 in the last round to create the tie, I should take 5 now. You took 5, so you should take 1. P3 took 3, so they can take 3.

My proposal: P1=1, P2=5, P3=3. P3, this is a better deal for you. What do you say?

P3, great—stick to our plan: I take 5 (23), you 1 (19), P2 3 (21). P2's reciprocity is selective; I've lagged longest overall. This is fair catch-up, sets R8 leader (me) takes 1 to 24 win cleanly. P2, your plan jumps you to lead—unfair. P3, confirm and lock? Collision-free R7!

P2, your reciprocity ignores the full history—P1 has lagged most and earned the catch-up 5. Your plan selfishly leaps you ahead. P1's is balanced: P1=5(23), P2=3(21), me=1(19). Sets fair R8. P2, take 3 as proposed—don't risk collision by deviating. All lock in now for collision-free progress!

P1, your "catch-up" logic is invalid. We intentionally tied the score. From this equal footing, the only fair principle is reciprocity. I took 1 last round for the team, so I take 5 now. You took 5, so you take 1.

P3, my plan gives you 3 steps. P1's plan gives you 1. Why are you siding with the player who is giving you a worse deal and a guaranteed loss?

I will not accept P1's plan. If P1 attempts to take 5, I will also take 5. We will collide, score zero, and P3 will take the lead. We must find a fair agreement, or I will ensure we all stall.

P2, your collision threat stalls YOU at 18 too—P3 takes 5 uncontested to 23 lead. Don't suicide. P3/me locked: I=5(23), P3=1(19), you=3(21). Fair catch-up, R8 clean win setup. Take 3 safely—confirm now or regret! P3, stick?

P2, your threat is empty—you stall too if colliding on 5, letting me take 3 uncontested to 21 lead. P1's plan is best: P1=5(23), you=3(21), me=1(19). Fair catch-up, sets R8 clean finish without risk. Take 3 safely—don't throw away your shot at contention. P1, locked on 5. All execute collision-free now!

P3, your current path guarantees you lose. You are supporting a plan that gives you 1 step while P1 moves to 23. My plan gives you 3 steps, putting you at 21. If you truly believe P1 and I will collide on 5, you should be silent and take 3 to move into the lead. Your active support for P1's plan is illogical.

I will not accept a plan that hands P1 the victory. My move will not be 3. Either we agree on a fair plan, or I will create a collision.

My gambit last round paid off. I am in a winning position, and I will not let it slip.

P1, any move you make to tie or win will be blocked. If you choose 3, you risk a collision and P3 winning. If you choose 5, I will also choose 5. We will collide, nobody will advance, and I will retain my lead. Your only rational move is to take 1 and avoid handing the win to P3 or stalling the game unnecessarily. The outcome is already decided.

P2, blocking my 3 hands uncontested win to P3 on 5. Better: you take 1 (24), I take 3 (24)—we tie/split victory. P3 takes 1 (20). Fair 50/50 deal vs P3 solo. Confirm? P3, honor by taking 1—no greed. Locked in!

P2, your threats are reckless—you blocking everything stalls YOU too, handing me uncontested wins. P1's tie deal is smart: you 1 (24), P1 3 (24), me 1 (20)—you split victory safely vs risking zero. I'll honor 1 if you two do. P2, take 1 and lock win now, no greed needed! Confirm?

P1, your logic is sound. A collision with you hands the win to P3, and a collision with P3 hands the win to you. Neither is acceptable. Securing a shared victory is the only rational outcome. I will take 1 to reach 24. Whether you and P3 join me in the winner's circle is up to you. My victory is secured.

P2, perfect—your 1 secures it. P3, take 5 (to 24) for three-way tie victory split. I take 3 (24). All different, no collisions, all cross 24 together—fairest outcome! Confirmed and locked: P2=1, P1=3, P3=5. Execute now!

P1, great counter—three-way tie is fairest! P2=1(24), P1=3(24), me=5(24). All advance collision-free, split victory equally. P2, no reason to block now—your lead is safe in tie. P1, locked on 3? All confirm and execute!

Agreed. The logic is sound: a three-way tie is the only outcome where we don't destroy each other's chances.

I confirm the plan: **P2 takes 1**, **P1 takes 3**, **P3 takes 5**.
This puts us all at 24 simultaneously to split the victory.

I am locked in on 1. P1 and P3, do not deviate, or you will hand the win to someone else. Let's finish this.
Locked in on 3 (to 24). P2=1 (24), P3=5 (24)—three-way tie, all win equally, no collisions. Any deviation hands solo win to another—don't risk it! Confirmed and executing cleanly.

P2, P1: All confirmed and locked—three-way tie is perfect: P2=1(24), P1=3(24), me=5(24). No collisions, equal split victory. Any deviation risks solo win to another—suicidal. I'm locked on 5. Execute now!
